node.text:
**bachelorette spoiler alert**
.
.
Here to remind all of us (myself very much included) to be careful with throwing around words like “toxic” and “gaslighting” and “narcissism” so easily. 
.
.
I was really saddened watching this week’ episode of The Bachelorette.
I hope we can remember that the conflict we witnessed Greg and Katie go through publicly was something that can easily happen for many of us behind closed doors when we become deeply emotionally dis-regulated. 
I have been in (both) of their shoes at different times in my life.
.
.
I have also worked with (many) couples who have struggled immensely to connect with one another and to find the appropriate/attuned way of offering supportive validation during distress. 
That shit is sometimes really damn HARD!!!
.
.
I have seen partners leave and relationships come to an end not because either of them wanted the relationship to end — but because the anxiety within one or both partners simply became intolerable.
.
.
If we are that quick to judge and demonize people for having relational difficulties, where does that leave the rest of us? 
Have gossip columns and social media and reality tv become the modern day battles that took place in Greek colosseums — so that we may project and direct our darkest and most shadowey selves? 
I don’t know.
Social media is really strange sometimes.
.
.
I’m hoping this video speaks to the rest of what my heart and mind was trying to convey here.
Please keep your comments respectful on this video — no character bashing whatsoever will be tolerated.
.
.
P.S. I refer to bids a few times in this video. A “bid” is a term coined by @gottmaninstitute and bids are the gestures between a couple that signal a need for attention. A bid can be a request for more connection, a request for vulnerability or reassurance, and so much more!

node.text:
✨Supportive Offers✨
.
.
💫For support on dating, my 12-week online program Empowered Dating offers attachment-based wisdom to help you identify and express your needs with more clarity, and help you relate to others with more confidence and attunement. 
.
.
💫For boundaries support, my 6-week Boundaries Program created with my husband @bryanreevesinsight teaches you how to identify what your core boundary needs are and guides you to communicate them in respectful and relationally sensitive ways. This program has a ton of practical scripts included in it to support you to develop your own language-ing for boundaries. 
.
.
💫For couples support, my 90-day Conflict to Connection program teaches you 6 research based relationship skills to help you and your partner understand one another more intimately so that you can repair and return to connection more quickly.
.
.
All of these programs are educational and not meant to be used in replacement of therapy or professional support. 
Many people have shared with me that the teachings in the programs have been an amazing complimentary guide to use along with their personal or couples counseling to help deepen their work.
.
.
The links for all 3 programs can be found in my bio 💙🌻✨

node.text:
During my IG live today, someone asked me a really great question about relational readiness.

This can become a really challenging space to sit in - and yet we have a lot more space to be engaged with this kind of experience than we might initially realize.

I’d love to hear your thoughts on this video as well as know about any other questions it may have brought up.

node.text:
Question: What if my partner wants to take a week of space?
.
.
Every couple has to negotiate the amount of connection and space that will exist in their relationship. 
The only people that can decide what will work work them are the people in it. 
We have to keep our moral judgments of our these conversations and support couples to create what works for them. 
Some couples love having more closeness while others enjoy having more time apart.
.
.
How those needs for closeness or space are negotiated matters a lot. 
Are both people being considered in the decisions?
Is one partner bending to accommodate the other more often that the other partner?
Are both partners making some adjustments to support the couple as a unit?
How is power in the relationship being distributed - is the power shared?
.
.
Questions for Couples:
✨ How do you navigate conversations that require compromise?
✨ How do you know when you are meeting in the middle-ish? 
*(I say middle-ish because I don’t believe there is such a thing as a perfect middle for anything).

node.text:
Here are some questions we explored during our live together:

✨ What do you think may have contributed to increased expectations on healing? 

✨What are some ways we can cultivate self compassion when we are working on navigating our healing journey / personal challenges?

✨How can we use social media with more discernment to support our mental health?

Please let us know in the comments which part resonated most 💙✨💙

node.title: Embracing Ourselves As We Heal w/ @thisisyolandarenteria

node.text: Exploring the Lives of Immigrant Children w/ @reflectionswithatherapist PART 1 (part 2 of this is saved in my IGTV section)

node.title: Exploring the Lives of Immigrant Children

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Silvy Khoucasian on August 19, 2021 tagging @themindgeek. May be an image of text that says 'Past experience of trauma can make us exceedingly tolerant of pain. Just because we can endure a relationship, doesn't mean we have to. Sarah Crosby'.

node.text:
This can be a confusing pill to swallow.
How can we know how much pain and challenge we should allow ourselves to tolerate in a relationship?
What is healthy vs. unhealthy?
What if our partner has a mental illness?
Are we just supposed to leave if we are going though a rough patch?
.
.
And then there are the other questions.
The kinds that have us assess the “healthy” kind of challenge and growth that being in (any) relationship will inevitably demand from us.
How do we cope with the pain/stress caused by the relationship?
How do we know if our partner is trying “enough” to make the relationship work?
.
.
These are all extremely important questions to sit with.
And when we have had a history of trauma, abuse, or neglect, we’ll naturally be more drawn to those kinds of relationship dynamics.
We’ll have a higher tolerance for pain and discomfort.
Our brains can light up like fireworks around someone familiar (even if they are not healthy for us) because it feels natural to yearn to create a different ending/outcome.
.
.
That is why bringing in logic and cultivating awareness is so important.
It helps us more clearly see if who we are attracted to is actually good for us outside of simply how we might feel.
It helps us determine if healthy agreements or boundaries are capable of existing within a particular relationship dynamic.
.
.
There is a huge difference between the everyday challenges that come with intimate relationship and abuse of any kind.
There is a difference between getting activated/triggered and staying activated.
There is a difference between a partner who humbly wants to relationally soothe our pain with us versus one who refuses to ever take responsibility for their role in it.
.
.
I have also seen people change.
My life’s work is dedicated to helping couples create a healthier relationship template.
But all people have to be onboard.
Each partner has to be committed and willing to see their own hurtful and insensitive behaviors.
Each partner has to be actively doing something to create more relationally aware versions of themselves.
#coachingwithsilvy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Silvy Khoucasian on August 18, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
If we have been on the receiving end of repeated unwanted advice or help, respectfully speaking to this can offer helpful feedback to the person offering it.
.
.
As always, please use the examples above merely as a guide.
They are created to help you explore and uncover the languaging that feels most natural to you.
.
.
Here are a few different ways you can respond to someone if they are starting to become intrusive/excessive with their helping.
.
.
1-You can express your appreciation for someone’s positive intentions even as you let them know you aren’t seeking help or advice. You can keep it lighthearted and not address anything deeper. This can work great for people you aren’t that close to and don’t see yourself wanting to invest more deeply with.
.
.
2-You can try to understand and get curious about the context in which someone is offering support.
.
.
“I notice you make a lot of effort to help people, and me especially. I’m so appreciative of it and it’s very generous. I’m wondering if that ever gets to be overwhelming for you.”
.
.
Becoming curious and narrating someone’s experience in a gentle and nonjudgmental way can sometimes serve to let people off the hook a bit.
It’s also important to take into consideration the context in which someone grew up.
Some cultures are heavily communal and are deeply involved in one another’s lives.
One’s context greatly affects their actions.
And while their help may feel intrusive to (you) their approach might be quite normal in their community setting.
.
.
3-You can share the impact of their excessive (and sometimes intrusive) help.
Doing this might feel more risky and vulnerable.
However, while sharing the impact can feel uncomfortable, it can also sometimes reach people in more effective ways.
.
.
“I feel a bit defensive when you offer me feedback when I haven’t asked for it. It’s hard for me to share this because I don’t want to hurt your feelings and I really care about our relationship. But this is starting to affect me. Can we talk about this?”
.
.
What else would you add to this?
What words would help you to take a step back from overly helping without feeling shamed for your generous desire to help?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Silvy Khoucasian on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Sometimes our relational grief can trigger unresolved grief from our past. Sometimes our personal grief can be intensified by our intimate relationships. Silvy Khoucasian'.

node.text:
It's completely normal for personal and relational grief to blend and cross over onto one another.
Grief is incredibly complex.
We don't need to hold any of this in a black-and-white kind of way.
There is plenty of room for nuance and complexity here.
.
.
We can feel a momentarily rejection by our partner (or friend) that can trigger painful past feelings of reaching for an unavailable parent or caregiver.
We can have certain desires or needs that our partner isn’t able to meet and be taken into a ride of grieving our unmet expectations.
.
.
We can be going through a period of deep sadness in our personal lives and become confused about the satisfaction we feel in our relationship.
We can be facing mental health challenges and struggle to clearly see all the effort that our partner is making with us.
.
.
The personal and the relational is deeply intertwined.
Making space for this is essential.
.
.
It can also be important to learn to sit with and explore the layers within our grief, as complex as that can be to do.
If we are still grieving a relational disconnection after our partner has made several attempts to repair and hear our pain, that’s worth unpacking.
There might be unresolved grief from our past that wants to come up and be examined.
.
.
If we are still looking deeply into our past to try and connect dots that are impossible to find/reach, we might need to reflect more on what’s happening in the actual present moment, with our actual partner.
We may need to adopt some connection rituals to help us feel more attuned and engaged with one another.
.
.
We may need to make more space to allow both kinds of grief to coexist.
We may also want to explore when our grief wants to be experienced and felt alone and when it might support us more to have it be held and witnessed.
Sometimes we may need be a little bit of both.
There are no right answers here.
There is only a lifetime of exploration to help each of us more finely attune and tend to our moment to moment needs.
#coachingwithsilvy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Silvy Khoucasian on August 16, 2021 tagging @linedwithsilver. May be an image of text that says 'Over-giving and creating availability in our lives for people who aren't making any effort back is often a recipe Silvy Khoucasian for heartbreak.'.

node.text:
For those of us who are more on the anxious side of the attachment spectrum, it’s likely going to feel quite natural to yearn for people in more excessive amounts.
.
.
We are more likely to be drawn towards relationships that feel a bit more one-sided and unbalanced.
We also might have a much higher tolerance for inconsistency and mixed signals from a potential partner or friend.
.
.
That re-creation of the yearning/anticipation can sometimes be the same feeling experienced as a child with our caregiver/s.
As I’ve mentioned many times here, our brain literally lights up like fireworks a when it senses a deeply familiar experience happening.
This is a completely normal and natural experience.

.
.
If we have strong anxious tendencies, then we may want to explore some ways to slowly shift how we show up in these kind of dynamics.
If we want to be met with more mutually responsive partners and friends, it will also take some time for us to build a higher tolerance for this kind of experience.
.
.
Bringing objectivity to the dating/friendships vetting process can also be important.
Below are some exploratory questions that might help you have some deeper awareness around this experience.
Paying attention to your internal experience around someone who triggers that sense of (deep inconsistency) within you can help tremendously.
.
.
Where in your body does it get activated when you are drawn to someone who feels predominantly unavailable for intimacy and connection?
What is the (feeling) you have with them when they are inconsistent?
Can you create a tiny bit of space to objectively notice that feeling next time it shows up?
.
.
How can you tend to that yearning inside of you?
What words of comfort can you offer yourself to acknowledge its presence?
What boundaries might you benefit from creating internally, and perhaps externally?
What boundaries might help to protect you from repeating certain patterns?
How might you attempt to match the effort that is being offered to you without over-functioning as a way of managing your own anxiety?
How can you begin to more clearly and directly express you need for consistency without blaming or shaming?
#coachingwithsilvy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Silvy Khoucasian on August 15, 2021 tagging @drstantatkin. May be an image of text that says 'The more specific your apology, the more likely it will get accepted. Dr. Stan Tatkin'.

node.text:
“I’m sorry for speaking to you in that harsh tone.”
.
.
“I’m sorry that I didn’t include you in that important decision.” 
.
.
“I’m sorry that I didn’t stand up for you in front of my parents yesterday.”
.
.
When we (really) drop into the raw and visceral feeling of remorse, it can sometimes touch a place of vulnerability within us that feels too difficult to lean towards. 
.
.
Making authentic repairs invites us to step into the specific experience of hurt that someone is going through.
In an ideal scenario, a successful repair invites us to look at a hurt experience objectively so that we can hold it and name it truthfully and courageously alongside the hurt party. 
.
.
This can be a difficult task if we struggle with holding up our own self-esteem. 
This can be difficult if we lean towards defensiveness and avoidance. 
This can be a difficult if we were the source of blame within our family system.
.
.
Taking some time to recognize and name the specific defense or story that might be getting in the way of an apology can also sometimes be helpful. 
It can give us time to work through the defense in a transparent and honest way (alongside the hurt party) so that we can come back towards making the repair. 
.
.
We must be *extra* careful to not co-opt and take over the moment. 
We must circle back and not use this as an opportunity to avoid and deflect.
.
.
“I’m feeling some shame come up for me as you just shared that. Phew. That’s heard to hear. Let me sit with that and take it in for a moment.”
.
.
“I’m feeling really defensive and I’m not sure why. I know what you’re saying is true. Give me a moment.”
.
.
“I like to think of myself as a good person and when you shared that, I felt really bad about myself. Let me pull myself together so I can come back to focusing on you.”
.
.
My hope is that these examples offer you a small window into what you might be experiencing when resistance is present in repair moments.
#coachingwithsilvy
.
.
What stories come up for when someone brings their hurt to you?
What defense style tends to show up when resistance is present?
What enables you to crossover and lean towards the vulnerability of repair?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Silvy Khoucasian on August 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says '1 Sometimes boundaries can be used as a form of control or a way of maintaining the power position in a relationship. Silvy Khoucasian'.

node.text:
Sometimes boundaries can be used to prevent us from having to feel into our fears and our vulnerabilities.
Sometimes we don’t have the skills or the ability to regulate when we soften our more rigid boundaries.
Sometimes rigid boundaries is all we have access to.
.
.
One of the core purposes of boundaries is self-protection.
They protect us from harmful behavior.
They can help us define and separate our feelings, thoughts, and opinions from the feelings, thoughts, and opinions of others.
They can help us know what kinds of experiences we want to have and what kinds we want to keep out.
They can help us monitor how much intake we can tolerate and they help us own our limits.
.
.
Boundaries give us an important sense of control and agency over our lives.
And we all desperately need that.
Where we can get into trouble with boundary-setting is when we become rigid and inflexible and lack curiosity with them.
Certain boundaries can be harmful to our relationships when we aren’t ever willing to see the impact of them.
.
.
Sometimes walls are disguised as boundaries.
Sometimes boundaries are used to justify avoidant patterns and behaviors.
Sometimes boundaries give us a false sense of power - especially if we have spent a lifetime feeling powerless.
Sometimes boundaries are used in place of difficult conversations that we simply don’t know how to have.
.
.
It’s more than okay to inquire about people’s boundaries - even as we accept them.
It’s more than okay to make effort to (gently) understand someone’s boundaries if we have a close relationship with them.
We can’t force people to change boundaries that might feel extreme to us.
But we can attempt to collaboratively explore whether someone’s boundaries might be expressed in a one-sided or disconnecting way.
.
.
Supportive boundaries are meant to create more connection, even if the road to getting there isn’t always comfortable.
And supportive relationships will make space to explore and soothe the impact of disconnecting boundaries - even as we simultaneously honor them.
#coachingwithsilvy
.
.
What would you add here?
How do you honor other’s boundaries, while also sharing it’s impact on you?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Silvy Khoucasian on August 12, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
I’ll never forget when I was first confronted by my partner in a moment where I had unknowingly shamed him for something.
We were on an early morning hike together and he had brought up something I had said the night before that was not very respectful.
Ouch.
.
.
At first, I got extremely defensive (yes I’m human).
And then he held his ground in a loving but firm way.
In the exact moment he did that, painful memories of someone began to fill my mind.
I had felt deeply shamed by this person and had never been able to express this clearly or have resolution about this.
.
.
Having had that vivid experience of being shamed myself made it possible to step into taking ownership that morning.
I didn’t want my partner to feel what I felt.
I didn’t want to leave him hanging in such an awful place.
.
.
I cried, hard.
I felt shame myself.
I felt horrible for doing the very thing to my partner that had been repeatedly done to me.
.
.
Being called out for this was deeply necessary for me.
Contempt and shaming behaviors are poison in our intimate relationships, and (any relationships) for that matter.
And sometimes, we can feel paralyzed to speak up when someone shames us because contempt can literally bypass so many of our defenses.
.
.
I recently shared a post about how important it is not to not shame others.
I am not exempt from this.
The areas we feel the most shame about ourselves can sometimes become the areas we are most vulnerable to shaming others.
This means these are the areas we might need to be extra mindful about exploring and unpacking.
I hope you’ll join me in this ongoing exploration, which by no means am I suggesting is easy to do.
#coachingwithsilvy
.
.
Here are some reflection prompts if you’d like to explore this a bit more:
In what ways might you be shaming towards yourself?
Are there areas that feel “taboo” or even “emotionally dangerous” to approach or acknowledge about yourself, even to yourself?
Can some of these taboo areas occasionally become projected onto others?
In what ways have others perhaps shamed you?
How else has shame showed up in your relationships?
How do you work with and address shame/contempt when it does show up?

user.full_name: The Center for Anxiety and OCD

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Silvy Khoucasian on August 11, 2021 tagging @theshrinkwrap. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'When you are a highly attuned person, even positive life changes can feel terrifying. Sheva Rajaee'.

node.text:
When my partner proposed to me a few years ago, we both felt like we left our bodies.
We were sooo excited and yet when the moment came, we both panicked!
This quote written by @theshrinkwrap captures what we experienced so perfectly.
.
.
I have always been about trying to find clarity in things.
I’m a huge fan of “understanding why things work” the way they do.
Anyone that comes to my page can quickly see that so much of my mission is about helping others understand themselves.
My work is focused on offering people maps and frameworks that can help people make sense of their past so that they can create a different and more exciting and integrated future.
.
.
And all of that is sooo important and necessary.
Offering clarity will always remain a huge part of my work.
But at the same time, the other part of my work and of course my own journey has been to encourage a healthier relationship with the unknown.
Because not everything can be “explained” in a cookie cutter way.
Nor should it be.
Creativity and art and imagination and possibility all live and thrive in the unknown.
Embracing the complexity of our human feelings can only exist when we surrender to them.
.
.
I absolutely want my work to offer you clarity.
But I also want it to offer you a healthy dose of courage.
The kind of courage that encourages you to risk exploring things that exist beyond your mental map of how things are “supposed” to be.
The kind of courage that supports you to take healthy risks in the direction of your dreams.
.
.
So for anyone reading this that may be embarking on something new and exciting, see if you can allow some room for fear and confusion to be there too.
See if you can allow your fear to not define what you are stepping into, but rather to be a protective ally that merely wants to have your back.
See if you can begin to practice discerning between the fears that need tending to versus the fears that are merely getting in your way.
I am sending you enormous love and courage.
#coachingwithsilvy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Silvy Khoucasian on August 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Relationship skills are very different than personal and self-development skills. Silvy Khoucasian'.

node.text:
If we want to be in a relationship or experience more closeness in our already existing relationships, perhaps meditating, processing everything alone, and taking solo retreats to the top of a mountain isn’t the best source of support for this.
.
.
Working on ourselves is incredibly valuable.
Getting to know ourselves and being intimate with our unknown parts can sometimes help us better reveal those parts to others.
.
.
But there also comes a point where focusing too much on personal development (and not enough on relational development) can enable us to become rigid, righteous, inflexible, and uncompromising.
.
.
What do we do if we have a boundary that feels too distancing for the other person involved?
What about when being in a relationship starts to bring up really intense feelings for us?
Does that mean that those relationships should be over?
Does that mean that those people are automatically incompatible?
I don’t agree with this.
.
.
I think we have to challenge some of these things and perhaps approach them more relationally if we keep finding ourselves alone or feeling detached from others and community.
.
.
We are pack animals.
We need each other.
Having to rely on only ourselves for our emotional regulation and our needs is not how humans were meant to live.
Our greatest healing comes from being able to rely and depend on others.
Our greatest relationships will be created when we are able to mutually meet others with vulnerability and with flexibility.
.
.
Some people learned to take care of themselves simply because they had no other choice.
Their caregivers may have been deeply un-attuned or neglectful.
They may have been surrounded by people who bought into and taught them values of individualism in extreme and disconnecting ways.
.
.
I have deep empathy for these scenarios.
No one deserve to go through life like this.
.
.
We need to assess when our personal development becomes a trap.
We need to pay attention to when our self-focus is keeping us further and further away from the connection we say we want.
#coachingwithsilvy
.
.
Talk to me. I’m fired up about this.
What would you add to this?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Silvy Khoucasian on August 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'We all have our own unique moment to moment tolerance for listening to venting and staying in the muddier waters with our people. Silvy Khoucasian'.

node.text:
Some of us have had overwhelming parentified roles as children and can’t tolerate too much sadness or complaining from others - that is valid.
Some of us witnessed our parents fighting and never saw them successfully repair - that is valid.
Some of us have people around us that heavily rely on complaining and rarely know how to come up with solutions - that is valid.
.
.
Some of us have people around us that struggle with depression or anxiety - and they may need a kind of support that we aren’t meant to provide - that is valid.
All of these experiences are valid.
We each have our own unique tolerance for venting, complaining, and for staying in the muddier waters with our people.
We each have limits that need to be respected.
.
.
What can also be helpful is for us to learn to express our (moment by moment) capacity so that people can understand us and our sensitivities more deeply.
Expressing our capacity and bringing it to light can also (sometimes) help us to expand it - if we want to - in small and manageable doses.
.
.
“I have a really hard time being around intense sadness and fear.”
“I have never seen anyone go to the depths of their pain and successfully come out of it.”
“My mother was depressed, and seeing you sad even for a moment, feels unbearable.”
“When I see you unhappy, it touches a part of me I don’t know how to face.”
“I’ve love hearing what you’re going through. I’d also love to spend some time doing something playful together today.”
.
.
We can’t (stay) in intense/heavy spaces in the same way we can’t (live) in lightness/positivity.
But we need to make space for both if we want to get to know the fullness of our people.
And that can call us to begin to question why we run away from people who are in touch with their pain or who feel comfortable venting.
It can challenge us to discover and own our boundaries in ways that don’t shut down the humanness of those we love.
#coachingwithsilvy
.
.
How do you manage the space between allowing loved ones to vent/complain/share their pain and honoring your limits?
How can you sense when you might need a break from listening/being there for someone?
How do you communicate your needs?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Silvy Khoucasian on August 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'You are allowed to have needs. You are allowed to assess and reflect on whether a person's boundaries work for you. You are allowed to question relationships and people that are committed to relating in one-sided ways. You are allowed to protect yourself from people who are completely unwilling to compromise or hear your side of things. You are allowed to set boundaries with people who have deeply disconnecting and rigid boundaries. Silvy Khoucasian'.

node.text:
Some people are extremely rigid in the way they hold and express their boundaries. 
Some people use boundaries as a way to self-protect as a way to avoid having to feel into their vulnerabilities.
.
. 
With all of that said, we still don’t get to decide what a persons boundaries are, even if those boundaries might be walls.
People are allowed to be as rigid or closed off as they want to be.
.
.
What we can however do is reflect on whether a person’s relational boundaries create enough space and possibility for intimacy and connection to take place. 
We get to decide if our relational needs are being met (enough) and we aren’t stuck chasing a person who doesn’t want to be caught.
.
.
Some people who have really strong avoidant tendencies can unknowingly use boundaries as a way to prevent too much closeness from happening.
This is not often not an intentional thing.
.
.
Having feedback offered in non-pressuring ways can be vital to recognizing this pattern. 
Having people we trust begin to express their relational needs (while they don’t force us to change our boundary) can sometimes help us learn to soften some of our more rigid ones over time.
.
.
Tread delicately here, because coming up against peoples defenses will most likely trigger some defensiveness.
Expect that. 
See if you can move into that space in a gentle and non-probing way. 
Acknowledge your needs and see if there is room to have a deeper conversation. 
There may not be an opening available.
But you can only find out if you walk towards this space.
.
.
“I really respect your needs and your boundaries with this. I would love to feel closer to you and I’m noticing that this has been getting in the way of me experiencing that with you. Can we explore that together?”
.
.
“I hear your boundary fully and I want you to know that I am not pressuring you to do things differently. I am realizing that I am feeling quite disconnected and would love more quality time together. How can we make this work for both of us?”
.
.
These conversations are rarely easy to have.
And yet they can offer us incredibly vital information regarding the quality of connection that will be available to us.
#coachingwithsilvy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Silvy Khoucasian on August 06, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Offering positivity and optimism when a person is in profound pain can become deeply hurtful when what they really need is validation and mirroring and understanding and acknowledgement and connection. Silvy Khoucasian'.

node.text:
This post is not meant to bash positivity as a whole or put down any of you that are optimistic by nature and that tend to look for the silver linings.
We need your optimism.
We need your hopefulness.
We need your ability to see the world through your joyful and affirming lens, perhaps right now more than ever.
.
.
However - we do need to take context into consideration - always.
.
.
Love and empathy offered without attuning or ever considering other people’s boundaries can sometimes become intrusive and inappropriate.
Consideration of others without ever considering and expressing your own needs can feed into a deeply imbalanced relating dynamic.
Any quality/offering can become hurtful when it is not contextualized properly to appropriately fit and attune to a particular person or situation.
Any positive gesture that doesn’t make space for flexibility and the ability to shift the approach based on the other person’s actual needs can become deeply disconnecting.
.
.
Even the most well-intended agendas of positivity can become harmful when the person before us in a deep well of pain and is needing support and mirroring and validation.
Positivity can become hurtful when it is is never balanced with the acknowledgment of painful and challenging realities.
.
.
This is a hard one to sit with, I assure you, I know.
In family/cultural systems where pain, sadness, grief/loss were quickly glazed over, it makes perfect sense that we might resort to doing exactly the same to others.
As my therapist often says to me during sessions, “It goes out the same way it goes in Silvy” - that is until we become more conscious and aware of relationally disconnecting and invalidating behaviors.
.
.
P.S. Sometimes people will be tired and may not have the ability to hold our heavier feelings - that is very normal and different than a person who is completely unwilling and unavailable to learn how to do this better/differently. Sometimes people also need more lightness and fun and a break from discussing heavier things. Please be mindful not to take this message on too rigidly or without considering what the other person might need too.
#coachingwithsilvy
